block.p: DEAR DIARY:

As I searched for a parking space at the Bernardsville ShopRite on Christmas Eve morning, I noticed that just exiting a space marked ''Expectant mothers only'' was a car with a man driving. Shaking my head, I watched as a car pulled into the space. It was occupied by two nuns. The miracle of Christmas.
TOM IORRIZZO

We recently put a deposit on a cemetery plot, and now it was time to make the final payment. I called to ask if the cemetery would accept Mastercard, and the woman on the other end of the line said, ''Certainly, what is your card number?''
I read all the digits of my account.
''What is the expiration date?'' she then asked.
I asked whether she wanted the expiration date of my card, or me.
She broke up with laughter.
GORDON D. RAPP

The holiday crowd in a Princeton supermarket was augmented by more than the usual folk the other day. And I wasn't the only person who was startled to see a sparrow fly down an aisle and land on a parked shopping cart.
As she grabbed cans of cat food off the shelf, a fellow shopper remarked: ''I guess this really is the pet aisle.''
LINDA OPPENHEIM
When I called my son Steve recently, my 4-year-old granddaughter, Lacey, answered the phone.
When I asked her to call Steve, I heard her say in the background, ''Daddy, the phone's for you.''
While waiting, I thought I would see if she understood our family relationship.
''Lacey, what is Steve to you?'' I asked.
She replied, ''Daddy.''
Then I asked, ''What am I to you?''
''Grandma,'' was her reply.
And finally I asked, ''What is Steve to me?''
Without hesitation, she answered. ''Good.''
FRED NUSSBAUM
(And speaking of children and telephones.)
I call a friend in New York the other day, and the conversation with her daughter went like this:
Me: ''Hi, May I speak with your mom?''
Child: ''. . . Um. O.K.''
(silence)
Me: ''Is she at home, sweetheart?''
Child: ''Y-y-y-e-s.''
Me: ''Can I talk to her please?''
Child: Can you hold on for 10 minutes?''
(silence)
Child: '' . . . and don't count, O.K.? . . . O.K?''
(silence)
I never did get to speak to my friend that day (sigh).
RAJ MERCHANT
FAREWELL, NOEL
'Twas the day after Christmas and all through the mall
Not a carol was heard that had blared throughout fall.
The Salvation Army was furloughed, I guess,
And reindeer had flown to another address,
The tannenbaum felled and the mistletoe missing,
With malcontent shoppers in no mood for kissing.
The creche is in storage, the Virgin released, her
Floor space relinquished to fashions for Easter.
For as 'twas with Christmas, without rhyme or reason,
The stores rush another liturgical season.
While, sheeplike, the People of God (every one!)
Queue up at ''Exchanges,'' Redemption's begun.
BOB McKENTY
